unnormalised: New Delhi – India is significantly increasing its renewable energy capacity, aiming for a greener future and reduced carbon footprint. Dr. Meena Sharma, head of the Renewable Energy Department at IIT-Bombay, highlighted the government's ambitious targets, including the installation of 500 GW of non-fossil fuel energy by 2030.
normalised: New Delhi – India is significantly increasing its renewable energy capacity, aiming for a greener future and reduced carbon footprint. Doctor Meena Sharma, head of the Renewable Energy Department at I I T-Bombay, highlighted the government's ambitious targets, including the installation of five hundred gigawatt of non-fossil fuel energy by two thousand and thirty.

unnormalised: Recent initiatives include the expansion of solar parks in Rajasthan and Gujarat, covering thousands of sq ft. Investment in wind energy projects along the Western Ghats has also increased. Furthermore, the Ministry of New and Renewable Energy is providing subsidies for rooftop solar installations, making renewable energy more accessible to individual households. Rs. 24,000 crore has been allocated for the promotion of green energy corridors, facilitating the transmission of renewable power from resource-rich regions to other parts of the country.
normalised: Recent initiatives include the expansion of solar parks in Rajasthan and Gujarat, covering thousands of square feet. Investment in wind energy projects along the Western Ghats has also increased. Furthermore, the Ministry of New and Renewable Energy is providing subsidies for rooftop solar installations, making renewable energy more accessible to individual households. Rupee twenty four thousand crore has been allocated for the promotion of green energy corridors, facilitating the transmission of renewable power from resource-rich regions to other parts of the country.

unnormalised: Challenges remain, including land acquisition and grid integration, but the commitment to renewable energy reflects India's dedication to environmental sustainability, following the principles of 'Prakriti Raksha' (Nature Conservation).
normalised: Challenges remain, including land acquisition and grid integration, but the commitment to renewable energy reflects India's dedication to environmental sustainability, following the principles of 'Prakriti Raksha' (Nature Conservation).
